results.title: Making a canoe
results.creator_credit: Peter Halket, Maurice Dybeck and Explorer Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Canoecraft”.
Two boys, with the help of an adult instructor, make a slalom canoe from glass reinforced plastic. The processes involved are shown step by step. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Making a bark canoe (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
A detailed description of the processes involved in making a bark canoe. Includes the proper way to remove the heavy water-soaked bark, the steam heating to make it pliable to shape the stern and bow, and the way to sew the ends together.

results.title: Making a balanced aquarium
results.creator_credit: Plymouth Productions and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Two children make a balanced aquarium in a glass tank. They demonstrate the step-by-step procedures of collecting soil and river gravel, placing these and the water in the tank, gathering and planting pond weeds, and then obtaining fish and other water animals to complete their aquarium.

results.title: Making 'The Girl from Tomorrow'
results.brief_description: The making of “The Girl from Tomorrow” provides teachers of media with an example of how this exciting series was made. Interviews with the director, Kathy Mueller and the producer, Noel Price are included along with technical information on just how the special effects were achieved.

results.title: Makin pitchas (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: Makin Pitchas is a compilation of four short films made by young Kooris who are a part of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative (BADAC). The project was an initiative funded by VicHealth to encourage young Kooris to explore and articulate their experiences of mental health issues, most particularly family issues, grief, conflict, racism and bullying. The final product is intended to promote discussion of mental health issues among young people in Indigenous communities as well as acting as a tool for cross cultural education in mainstream organisations. “Believe in Yourself” (dir. Tim Stares) is the story of Dave, a koori youth who feels alienated and discouraged by his parents who would prefer he drop out of school and lay bricks for his father rather than follow his dream to be a filmmaker. “A World of Colour” (dir. Myles Walsh) focuses on a mediation session, after a basketball game turns into a racial slagging match. “Goodnight Irene” (dir. Tim Stares) tells the story of Ruth, a young girl who has to do a history project about family’s pastimes. Unfortunately she cannot report anything to her teacher because the memories her mother has of her past are too painful to discuss. In “Verandah Dreaming” (dir. Myles Walsh) Verna loses her husband in the war and her son to drugs. Hope seems further lost when her grandson is sent to prison for stealing a car. However, with the help of the Aboriginal Legal Service, Sammy joins an Aboriginal Dance group and finds direction to his life.

results.title: Makin' up!. The Most beautiful breasts in the world
results.creator_credit: Ewa Karlstrom, Vela-X Filmproduktion and Katja Von Garnier
results.brief_description: Makin’ Up! (1992, 54 mins.) is an endearing comedy that focuses on the friendship between two women, Frenzy (Katja Riemann), a cynical, independent cartoonist, and Maischa (Nina Kronjager), a nurse desperately trying to find Mr Right. When Maischa scores a date with a man she has been lusting after, Frenzy is reluctantly forced to entertain his friend for the night. Neither of these interactions turns out as they expected and while both women are forced to re-evaluate their attitudes to romantic love, they realise that while men come and go, their lasting friendship will always provide them with constant pleasure and emotional support. “Makin’ Up!” is peppered with laughs, never taking itself too seriously. It is characterised by strong writing, inventive direction, and a rare chemistry between the two main characters. “The Most Beautiful Breasts in the World” (1990, 15 mins. prods/dirs, Thomas Wobke, Rainer Kaufmann) is a frivolous fantasy about a businessman who unexpectedly finds he has acquired a pair of prominent breasts. Both films in German with English subtitles.

results.title: Makeshift solutions
results.brief_description: Sixth in a series of nine animated films on the history of western civilization. Looks at the rise of capitalism during the 19th century; examines the formation of trusts, cartels and monopolies; and discusses the use of cheap labour and cheap raw materials.
results.description: Sixth in a series of nine animated films on the history of western civilization. Looks at the rise of capitalism during the 19th century; examines the formation of trusts, cartels and monopolies; and discusses the use of cheap labour and cheap raw materials.

results.title: Makers of wine
results.brief_description: A survey of the Australian wine industry showing how wine is made, and some of the by-products which are produced in addition to excellent table wines. For wine grapes to grow well, soil and climate must be right; various types of soil are more suitable for some kinds of wine-grapes than others. In Australia, irrigation in the Murray Valley has helped the wine industry, for in many areas where wine is now produced, soil and general climate are suitable, but the rainfall is inadequate. Narrated by John Sherwood.

results.title: Make your senate vote count
results.brief_description: Bill Peach of ABC’s “This Day Tonight” explains how to vote correctly in a Senate election. In the last Senate election nearly half a million informal votes out of a possible 6 million, were cast and could not be counted. Tells the five simple steps to avoid mistakes.
